slide.text: Let’s refresh some concepts that will come in handy as you start the conic sections unit of the high school geometry course. You’ll see a summary of each concept, along with a sample item, links for more practice, and some info about why you will need the concept for the unit ahead. This article only includes concepts from earlier courses. There are also concepts within this high school geometry course that are important to understanding right triangles and trigonometry. If you have not yet mastered the [Distance and midpoints lesson](/math/geometry/hs-geo-analytic-geometry#hs-geo-distance-and-midpoints), it may be helpful for you to review that before going farther into the unit ahead. ##Radius and diameter ###What is this, and why do we need it? A circle is the collection of all points that are a certain distance from its center. We use the word **radius** both to mean that distance (a number) and to mean any segment (a geometric figure) with one endpoint on the center of the circle and one endpoint on its circumference. Similarly, the **diameter** can mean either the widest distance across the circle, which is $2$ times the radius, or any segment that passes through the center of the circle with both endpoints on the circumference of the circle. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group 1]] For more practice, go to [Radius and diameter](/e/radius_diameter_and_circumference). ###Where will we use this? We use this vocabulary throughout the unit. Here is the first exercise where reviewing the radius and diameter might be helpful: - [Graph a circle from its features](/e/graph-a-circle-according-to-its-features) ##Pythagorean theorem ###What is this, and why do we need it? The Pythagorean theorem is $a^2+b^2=c^2$, where $a$ and $b$ are lengths of the legs of a right triangle and $c$ is the length of the hypotenuse. The theorem means that if we know the horizontal and vertical distances between any two points, we can find out the distance between the points. We can use the Pythagorean theorem to find the length of the radius of a circle, to derive the equation of a circle, and to derive the equation of a parabola. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] For more practice, go to [Use Pythagorean theorem to find right triangle side lengths](/e/pythagorean_theorem_1). ###Where will we use this? Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing the Pythagorean theorem might be helpful: - [Features of a circle from its graph](/e/find-the-features-of-a-circle-from-its-graph) - [Features of a circle from its standard equation](/e/equation_of_a_circle_1) - [Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix](/e/equation-of-parabola-from-focus-and-directrix) ##Completing the square ###What is this, and why do we need it? There is a pattern when we square a binomial: $(x+b)^2=x^2+2bx+b^2$ We complete the square when we have an equation like $x^2+2bx=c$, and we find the value $b^2$ to add to both sides. Then the left side of the equation becomes a perfect square. Rewriting equations for circles by completing the square puts it back in the form of the Pythagorean theorem so that we can see the coordinates of the circle's center and the square of the radius. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 2]] For more practice, go to [Completing the square (intro)](/e/completing_the_square_in_quadratic_expressions), [Completing the square (intermediate)](/e/completing_the_square_1), and [Completing the square](/e/completing_the_square_2). ###Where will we use this? Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing completing the square might be helpful: - [Features of a circle from its expanded equation](/e/equation_of_a_circle_2) - [Graph a circle from its expanded equation](/e/graphing_circles_2)

slide.text: ## What is the standard equation of a circle? $(x-\blueD h)^2+(y-\maroonD k)^2=\goldD r^2$ This is the general **standard** equation for the circle centered at $(\blueD h, \maroonD k)$ with radius $\goldD r$. Circles can also be given in **expanded form**, which is simply the result of expanding the binomial squares in the standard form and combining like terms. For example, the equation of the circle centered at $(\blueD 1,\maroonD 2)$ with radius $\goldD 3$ is $(x-\blueD 1)^2+(y-\maroonD 2)^2=\goldD 3^2$. This is its expanded equation: $\begin{align} (x-\blueD 1)^2+(y-\maroonD 2)^2&=\goldD 3^2 \\\\ (x^2-2x+1)+(y^2-4y+4)&=9 \\\\ x^2+y^2-2x-4y-4&=0 \end{align}$ *Want to learn more about circle equations? Check out [this video](/v/radius-and-center-for-a-circle-equation-in-standard-form).* ## Practice set 1: Using the standard equation of circles [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/equation_of_a_circle_1) and [this exercise](/e/graphing_circles).* ## Practice set 2: Writing circle equations [[☃ graded-group-set 2]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/write-the-equation-of-a-circle).* ## Practice set 3: Using the expanded equation of circles To interpret the expanded equation of a circle, we should rewrite it in standard form using the method of "completing the square." Consider, for example, the process of rewriting the expanded equation $x^2+y^2+18x+14y+105=0$ in standard form: $\begin{align} x^2+y^2+18x+14y+105&=0 \\\\ x^2+y^2+18x+14y&=-105 \\\\ (x^2+18x)+(y^2+14y)&=-105 \\\\ (x^2+18x\redD{+81})+(y^2+14y\blueD{+49})&=-105\redD{+81}\blueD{+49} \\\\ (x+\redD9)^2+(y+\blueD7)^2&=25 \\\\ (x-(-9))^2+(y-(-7))^2&=5^2 \end{align}$ Now we can tell that the center of the circle is $(-9,-7)$ and the radius is $5$. [[☃ graded-group-set 3]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/equation_of_a_circle_2) and [this exercise](/e/graphing_circles_2).*

lecture.lecture_title: Focus and directrix of a parabola

slide.text: ## What are conic sections? Conic sections are the shapes you get when you slice a cone at different angles. There are four types of conic sections: ellipses, hyperbolas, parabolas, and circles. ## Where are conic sections used in the real world? Conic sections show up in a lot of places! For example, the orbits of planets around the sun are elliptical. Hyperbolas are often used in the design of telescopes and antennas. Parabolas are important in physics, as they describe the shape of projectiles in flight. ## What is the standard equation of a circle? The standard equation of a circle looks like $(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2$. When the equation is in this form, the center of the circle is located at $(h,k)$ and has a radius of $r$. For example, the equation $(x+2)^2+(y-3)^2=16$ represents a circle with center $(-2,3)$ and radius $4$. ## What do we mean by the focus and directrix in parabolas? A parabola can be graphed as the set of all points that are equidistant from a fixed point (the "focus") and a fixed line (the "directrix"). ## How can we find the equation of a parabola from its focus and directrix? We use the fact that any point $(x,y)$ on the parabola must be equidistant from the focus and directrix. Consider, for example, the parabola whose focus is at $(-3,6)$ and directrix is $y=4$. We start by assuming a general point on the parabola $(x,y)$. Using the [distance formula](/a/distance-formula-review), we find that the distance between $(x,y)$ and the focus $(-3,6)$ is $\sqrt{(x+3)^2+(y-6)^2}$, and the distance between $(x,y)$ and the directrix $y=4$ is $\sqrt{(y-4)^2}$. On the parabola, these distances are equal: $\begin{align} \sqrt{(y-4)^2} &= \sqrt{(x+3)^2+(y-6)^2} \\\\ (y-4)^2 &= (x+3)^2+(y-6)^2 \\\\ \blueD{y^2}-8y\goldD{+16} &= (x+3)^2\blueD{+y^2}\maroonD{-12y}+36 \\\\ -8y\maroonD{+12y}&=(x+3)^2+36\goldD{-16} \\\\ 4y&=(x+3)^2+20 \\\\ y&=\dfrac{(x+3)^2}{4}+5\end{align}$

## What are the focus and directrix of a parabola? Parabolas are commonly known as the graphs of quadratic functions. They can also be viewed as the set of all points whose distance from a certain point (the **focus**) is equal to their distance from a certain line (the **directrix**). [[☃ image 1]] *Want to learn more about focus and directrix of a parabola? Check out [this video](/v/focus-and-directrix-introduction).* ## Parabola equation from focus and directrix Given the focus and the directrix of a parabola, we can find the parabola's equation. Consider, for example, the parabola whose focus is at $(-2,5)$ and directrix is $y=3$. We start by assuming a general point on the parabola $(x,y)$. Using the [distance formula](/a/distance-formula-review), we find that the distance between $(x,y)$ and the focus $(-2,5)$ is $\sqrt{(x+2)^2+(y-5)^2}$, and the distance between $(x,y)$ and the directrix $y=3$ is $\sqrt{(y-3)^2}$. On the parabola, these distances are equal: $\begin{align} \sqrt{(y-3)^2} &= \sqrt{(x+2)^2+(y-5)^2} \\\\ (y-3)^2 &= (x+2)^2+(y-5)^2 \\\\ \blueD{y^2}-6y\goldD{+9} &= (x+2)^2\blueD{+y^2}\maroonD{-10y}+25 \\\\ -6y\maroonC{+10y}&=(x+2)^2+25\goldD{-9} \\\\ 4y&=(x+2)^2+16 \\\\ y&=\dfrac{(x+2)^2}{4}+4\end{align}$ *Want to learn more about finding parabola equation from focus and directrix? Check out [this video](/v/equation-for-parabola-from-focus-and-directrix).* ## Check your understanding [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/equation-of-parabola-from-focus-and-directrix).*
